<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of connection_shrink_read_buffer:
```c
static void
connection_shrink_read_buffer (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; /**< a short alias */
  void *new_buf;

  if ((NULL == c->read_buffer) || (0 == c->read_buffer_size))
  {
    mhd_assert (0 == c->read_buffer_size);
    mhd_assert (0 == c->read_buffer_offset);
    return;
  }

  mhd_assert (c->read_buffer_offset <= c->read_buffer_size);
  if (0 == c->read_buffer_offset)
  {
    MHD_pool_deallocate (c->pool, c->read_buffer, c->read_buffer_size);
    c->read_buffer = NULL;
    c->read_buffer_size = 0;
  }
  else
  {
    mhd_assert (MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace (c->pool, c->read_buffer, \
                                               c->read_buffer_size));
    new_buf = MHD_pool_reallocate (c->pool, c->read_buffer, c->read_buffer_size,
                                   c->read_buffer_offset);
    mhd_assert (c->read_buffer == new_buf);
    c->read_buffer = new_buf;
    c->read_buffer_size = c->read_buffer_offset;
  }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
new_buf = MHD_pool_reallocate (c->pool, c->read_buffer, c->read_buffer_size,
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in this fragment: c->read_buffer is used as a modifiable memory buffer and is passed to a pool reallocation routine that may change the memory (and returns a non-const void *). Rule 8.13 recommends using const-qualified pointed-to types only when the object is not modified — that is not the case here. A concrete violation scenario would be if the buffer were actually immutable (e.g. declared const void *read_buffer or pointing at a string literal) but code passed it as a plain void * (dropping const), or if the function did not modify the pointed-to data and the pointer type could have been declared const but was not.
